journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: The non-closed parts optimal fitting method based on curvature Hausdorff distance using 3D non-contact measurement points

article-meta.aff: 1Shanghai Key Laboratory of Digital Autobody Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China
2Department of Mathematics, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Hua Wang, School of Mechanical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, No. 800 Dongchuan Rd., Shanghai 200240, People’s Republic of China. Email: huawang@sjtu.edu.cn

abstract.p: Auto-body panel fitting is an efficient way to improve dimensional quality and to give a better impression to the consumers. Optimal panel fitting has been studied by many authors, and the proposed optimization models mainly concerned the optimized fitting position for two closed parts. The fitting problem of the front and rear parts of a car is different from the closed parts fitting problem, because the fitting parts are non-closed. The purpose of this research was to develop systematic and efficient methods for optimal fitting of non-closed parts using 3D non-contact measurement points. B-spline curve fitting was employed to obtain fitting boundaries from point cloud data. A new fitting model for non-closed parts based on curvature Hausdorff distance was proposed to obtain the optimal fitting quality. The validity of the minimal curvature Hausdorff distance corresponding to optimal fitting quality was verified by a practical demonstration. A practical fitting case of the hood, headlight and fender of a car was conducted and optimal fitting quality was achieved. The results of this research will enhance the understanding of the optimal fitting of spatial curves, and help systematically adjust the non-closed fitting parts.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The dimensional integrity of the automotive body (body-in-white) had great effects on the quality and functionality of the vehicle.1 Part measurement systems used in automotive body applications largely consist of discrete point inspection. Three measurement gauges were most often used for checking part/assembly dimensions: (1) hard gauge fixtures and layout plates; (2) coordinate measuring machines (CMM); and (3) optical coordinate measuring machines (OCMM).1 As a result, automotive body manufacturers often seek to minimize the number of discrete inspection points to reduce costs.

One concern with trying to minimize the number of discrete measurement locations is that a manufacturer may not fully comprehend potential problem areas.2 For instance, some part characteristics such as flatness, parallelism of a mating surface, or trim edge consistency become very difficult to evaluate using discrete points, as each of these characteristics requires multiple discrete points to estimate. A further concern with discrete point checking systems is that a manufacturer may not be able to pre-define which discrete point locations are critical during the part design and development process. Thus, manufacturers often incur significant costs during the product lifecycle for adding, changing, or deleting discrete point locations.

The 3D non-contact measurement systems that generated point cloud data complemented the shortcomings of the traditional discrete point checking systems. These 3D non-contact point cloud systems generated point cloud data, which consisted of thousands of point measurements meshed together to represent a full part shape.

Modification and updating of current car models is mostly concentrated in the front part (hood, headlights, bumpers and fender) and the rear part (trunk, taillights, bumpers and fender). It is a most challenging job in body-in-white assembly to obtain the optimal gap and flushness of the front and rear parts. Poor gap and flushness quality affects not only the appearance of the car but also its performance, causing, among other problems, increased air noise, more air resistance, water leakage and many other issues.

The front appearance of an auto-body gives the first impression to the customer, and it has a great impact on purchasing decisions (Figure 1). Auto-body panel fitting is an efficient way to improve dimensional quality and to give the customer a good impression. In order to obtain good dimensional quality, the engine hood, fenders and the headlights are designed to be adjustable components. The common adjustment strategy takes the hood as the reference part and then adjusts headlight, fender and front bumper accordingly. It is difficult to determine an optimal fitting position because there are three or more components that need to be coordinated. Good fitting quality is obtained by adjusting these components while assembling, and it is time-consuming work. Different workers have different experiences and different fitting results are produced, resulting in low production efficiency.

caption.p: Fitting defect in front of a car.

sec.p: To improve auto-body panel fitting quality, the uniformity and smoothness of the gap and flushness, lots of research had been conducted. The fitting of rigid bodies was studied by Bona and Menga,3 who treated it as a minimization problem. An approach for feeding back in-process measurement data to the panel fitting process was suggested by Wu et al.4 Wu5 presented three indexes of gap quality: (1) door gap width deviation relative to design nominal; (2) door gap parallelism; and (3) car-to-car gap consistency. Then the door-fitting problem was formulated into a general constrained optimization problem.

Khorzad6 presented a systematic approach to obtain improved panel fitting quality through the use of an optimum panel fitting strategy. Fainberg and Zussman7 studied the fitting problem of a 2D closed surface; they simplified the problem to a two planar closed curves fitting problem, and a ‘peg-in-hole’ model was presented. Calafiore and Bona8 addressed the problem of 3D optimal fitting under geometrical constraints. Luo9 developed an algorithm based on genetic algorithms (GA) to solve such problems. Zhu10 employed the Hausdorff distance between two continuous closed panels as the measure to evaluate the fitting quality of car door fitting. A genetic algorithm was used to search optimal fitting variables in a global and parallel way.

The optimal fitting models suggested above mainly concerned the optimal fitting position for two closed parts. The fitting problem of the front parts (hood, headlights, bumpers and fender) and the rear parts (trunk, taillights, bumpers and fender) of an auto-body was a large-scale 3D surfaces fitting problem. It was a non-closed parts optimal fitting problem and was different from the closed parts fitting problem (‘peg-in-hole’ model). The two planar closed curves in the closed parts fitting problem were similar closed curves, and it only concerned the positioning of two parts. The front and rear parts of an auto-body are non-closed parts and are different from car-door fitting. The front and rear parts concerned are non-closed curves, and they were similar to each other only in fitting section. Two fitting parts’ non-closed curves create a new boundary, and the third part fits this new boundary. A new fitting model for non-closed parts must be developed to obtain the optimal fitting position of the front and rear parts (Figure 2).

caption.p: Auto-body fitting quality, gap and flushness.

sec.p: The paper develops a systematic and efficient method for non-closed parts optimal fitting based on the curvature Hausdorff distance (CHD) using 3D non-contact measurement systems. The next section reviews related research work on panel fitting. The following section develops the curvature Hausdorff distance as a measurement function of gap and flushness, and introduces the establishment of the non-closed panel fitting model. A practical case is then presented, and the optimal fitting problem is resolved by a genetic algorithm.

sec.title: Curve fitting
sec.p: The B-spline approach has been widely used in image processing, and can approximate to the given curve through a set of control points and B-spline blending functions. The outstanding advantage of this approach is that changes in local spline curve do not have long-distance effects.11 B-spline curve fitting was employed to facilitate building the fitting function and solving the optimal fitting problem.
Suppose that knot vector T = (t0, t1, t2, …) is given, there are control points Pk (0≤k<L+l) and mth-degree B-spline blending function. B-spline curve representation can thus be expressed as
In addition, the standard knot vector with (L+l) control points and mth-degree B-spline blending function is always described as

Three coordinates and parameters, t, were fitted, respectively; that is, x = x(t), y = y(t) and z = z(t). It helped to find the optimal solutions and the curve fitting results was independent on the coordinate system.

sec.title: Offset direction
sec.p: One key step of non-closed curves fitting is curve offset. Figure 3 shows the curves in different offset modes. Offset direction is a most important parameter.

The distances between the original curve and the offset curve are equal in the proposed CHD optimization method. In order to achieve this goal, a new offset direction calculating method is proposed (Figure 4).

caption.p: Different offset of curves.
Schematic diagram of normal vector of space curves.

sec.p: For the spatial curve, the offset vector, n2, is

Solving equations (20) and (21) gives the offset points.

sec.title: Fitting model of non-closed parts
sec.p: The front and rear parts of an auto-body are large-scale three-dimensional fitting surfaces and they are non-closed panels. The front part and the rear part can be abstracted into one fitting model, and the front part was chosen as a demonstration to explain the fitting model and the solving process. The optimal fitting position of the hood, headlight and fender of an auto-body is represented by three fitting components, namely, the fitting of the three non-closed spatial curves (Figure 5).

caption.p: Abstracting three fitting parts into three non-closed curves.

sec.title: Curvature Hausdorff distance (CHD)
sec.p: Hausdorff distance (HD),10,13 a maximum–minimum function derived from notation of set distance, is one of the frequently-used similarity measures in geometric pattern matching algorithms to evaluate the similarity of an image to a template. The smaller the HD, the higher the degree of similarity. Judging by this criterion, best fitting position can be determined between the image and the template. Therefore the authors attempted to use this as the fitting quality criteria for best fitting of panels and corresponding auto-body openings.
The optimal fitting position of the hood, headlight and fender of an auto-body is represented by the three non-closed space curves fitting (Figure 6).

caption.p: Non-closed fitting curves.

sec.p: The optimal three curves fitting quality implies the perfect offset, the offset between the offset curve (curve c’), which fits with two non-closed curves (curve a and curve b), and the original curve (curve c). Curvature is a very effective evaluation for the perfect offset.

Curvature at any point on the surface is the measure of how rapidly the surface pulls away from the tangent plane in the neighbourhood of that point.14 Digital curvature is computed from a discrete set of points, either representing a digital line or the discrete boundary of some digital object. In fact, these discrete points are the representation of some continuous pre-digitized object. The differential geometric properties of a surface, such as curvature at a point and the principal directions of curvature, are widely used for shape registration and recognition, 3D computer vision and in image understanding, due to their frame independence.15

It was the middle section of the fitting curve, c’, that determines the similarity between the two curves. When curve a and curve b are close, that is, the gap between a and b is small, the curvature of the middle section of the fitting curve, c’, is large.

The greater the gap between curves a and b, the less the curvature of the middle section of c’. Curvatures of the fitting curves are adopted into the Hausdorff distance idea to evaluate the similarity between the two curves, c and c’. The minimum curvature Hausdorff distance (CHD) corresponds to the optimal position of curve a, b and c.

Curves c and c’ (Figure 6) have different curvatures and they are similar in shape. The consistency between curvatures has a significant impact on fitting quality. The curvature estimating procedure of three fitting curves, and the problem-solving procedure, is shown in Figure 7.

caption.p: Flow chart of optimizing fitting based on CHD.

sec.title: Correlation between CHD and fitting quality
sec.p: The correlation between CHD and fitting quality, that is, the validity of the minimal CHD corresponding to optimal fitting quality, can be verified by a practical demonstration of three planar curves fitting.

Three fitting planar curves are shown in Figure 8.

sec.p: According to the steps mentioned above, the optimal fitting model based on CHD is constructed (Figure 10)

sec.title: Case study
sec.p: Take the left front of a car, that is the engine hood (A), fender (B) and the left headlight (C), as an example (Figures 11 and 12) to demonstrate the whole procedure of non-closed parts fitting based on CHD.

caption.p: Scenario of the case study.
Fitting condition in the left front of a car.

sec.p: The whole procedure of non-closed parts fitting is shown in Figure 13. First, the fitting parts are scanned and point clouds are processed to get the boundaries of the fitting parts. Second, CHDs of the fitting parts are calculated and the parameters are initialized. Third, the optimization object and constraint conditions are initialized. Then the optimal problem is resolved with a genetic algorithm (GA). Finally, the best non-closed panel fitting quality and adjustment variables are obtained.

caption.p: The whole procedure of non-closed parts fitting.

sec.title: Fitting parts scanning and point cloud processing
sec.p: A COMET 400 laser scanner was used to scan the front of a car. This process included scanning the fitting parts, multi-perspective point cloud registration, point cloud filtering (or point cloud de-noising), point cloud smoothing and feature extraction of point clouds (Figure 11).

Because the fitting parts are too large to be scanned in one shot, multi-perspective point cloud registration was conducted. Marked reference points for registration in the scanning area were employed (Figure 14). Multi-perspective point cloud registration was accomplished in the COMET PLUS software (Figure 14).

caption.p: Scanning scene and the point cloud.

sec.p: Point cloud filtering and point cloud smoothing were conducted in IMAGEWARE software and the final point cloud is shown in Figure 15.

caption.p: De-noising and filtering of the point cloud.

sec.title: Curve fitting of mating parts
sec.p: Fitting boundaries were obtained by the B-spline fitting method proposed earlier from the point cloud. The samples of fitting boundaries were as follows

The measuring point information was input into the self-developed program and the initial position of fitting parts’ boundaries are shown in Figure 16, where A1 represents the A curve’s segment fitting with curve C, A2 represents the A curve’s segment fitting with curve B, B1 represents the B curve’s segment fitting with curve A, B2 represents the B curve’s segment fitting with curve C, C1 represents the C curve’s segment fitting with curve B and C2 represents the C curve’s segment fitting with curve A. OB and OC are the offset reference points of curves B and C.

caption.p: Initial position boundary constructed by feature points.

sec.p:
Parts A, B and C’s boundary is expressed by
r = ( x ( t ) , y ( t ) , z ( t ) )
, respectively, where t is the serial number of the checking points. Following the steps proposed in an earlier section, the curvature and offset direction of fitting the parts was obtained. The standard deviation σ was set to six in the Gaussian function
G ( t , σ )
and the gap was set to two, according to the design requirements.

sec.title: Optimal fitting model and problem solving with GA
sec.p:
According to the above steps, the optimal fitting model based on CHD was constructed with equation (23). According to the design requirements and suggestions from experienced engineers, the three parts’ fitting weight coefficients were

Genetic algorithms (GAs)16 are a widely used efficient method of random search and optimization based on the principle of evolution. A GA was employed to search for the optimal solution of the fitting problem, and the optimization procedure is shown in Figure 17.

caption.p: Steps of GA-based fitting optimization.

sec.p: The GA’s genetic algebra was set to 500 and the population size was 20. The GA optimization process is shown in Figure 18 and the final optimal results are shown in Table 3 and Figure 19.

caption.p: Optimization process of GA.
GA parameters and optimization results (units: mm and degrees).

tr.td: Shift and rotation of OB:(x, y, z, α, β, γ)
Shift and rotation of OC:(x, y, z, α, β, γ)

caption.p: Optimization solution and program interface.

sec.p: Adjusting the fitting parts according to the adjustment parameters, the fitting gap and flushness are both within design requirements, which verifies the feasibility of this method.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The front appearance of a car is very important for the first impression of the customer. Auto-body panel fitting quality is an efficient way to improve dimensional quality and to give a better impression to the customer. A new non-closed parts fitting model based on curvature Hausdorff distance (CHD) has been developed to obtain the optimal fitting position. The correlation between CHD and fitting quality, that is, the validity of the minimal CHD corresponding to optimal fitting quality, has been verified by a practical demonstration of three curves fitting. A practical fitting case of the hood, headlight and fender of a car has been conducted and good fitting quality has been achieved.

To get a good auto-body panel fitting quality, scanning point cloud data was employed. The B-spline curve fitting was employed to obtain fitting boundaries. The curvature calculation methods and the offset algorithm were developed according to the requirements of non-closed parts fitting.

Finally, through the estimation of a part’s fitting curve’s curvature, the optimal fitting model of non-closed parts based on CHD was established. The constrained optimization model can not only satisfy the design requirements on gap and flushness, but also found the optimal solution easily.
The results of this research will enhance the understanding of the optimal fitting of spatial curves, and help systematically adjust non-closed fitting parts.

ack.p: The author is also grateful to Mr Jike Xu and Mr Fuhua Zhang who conducted the experiments and provided some data and material in the paper.
